page.title: Exclamations and Greetings
page.introduction: This section considers various types of common utterances which are not complete sentences. We will deal with greetings, interjections and exclamations in turn.

form.introduction: Greetings typically consist of a particular word or phrase, either standing alone or followed by a name or nominal phrase describing the peson or animal being greeted. Those that are full sentences or full questions, such as How do you do? and How are you? and Have a good day! will parse automatically and do not need special treatment here. form.introduction: Exclamations typically consist of a particular word, such as how in English, followed by an adjective phrase and usually punctuated with an exclamation point. English examples include:

EnglishExample.exItem: How wonderful that your family could come!

radioGroup.radio: No, there are separate sets for each side

form.instruction: In the lexicon, add the feature makeExcl to each word which signals an exclamation to assure the proper category for the syntax.

In the lexicon, add the feature excl-initial to each word which signals an exclamation that only occurs before the adjective phrase and add the feature excl-final to each word which signals an exclamation that only occurs after the adjective phrase. Do not add either feature to any words which may occur either before or after the adhjective phrase.
